thread.title: KU football wideout Jeremiah Booker one of few bright spots against Baylor
thread.title_full: KU football wideout Jeremiah Booker one of few bright spots against Baylor

author: Ben Felderstein
title: KU football wideout Jeremiah Booker one of few bright spots against Baylor
text:
KU football wideout Jeremiah Booker one of few bright spots against Baylor Freshman hauls in 39 yards on three catches in debut Posted: October 14, 2015 - 7:52pm Photos SUBMITTED/KU ATHLETICS KU football wideout Jeremiah Booker hauled in three catches for 39 yards in his season debut last Saturday against Baylor. Booker had been limited by a left shoulder injury suffered in early August. By Ben Felderstein The Capital-Journal 
One thing Kansas football coach David Beaty has preached since the beginning of his time at KU has been, “Earn it.” Beaty has been saying it since Day 1, and if a player works hard and does what he needs to do, the coach has said he will play. 
According to teammates Kent Taylor and Jordan Shelley-Smith, 6-foot-2 freshman Jeremiah Booker has been “earning it” since he arrived at camp. Beaty says the first thing that comes to mind when thinking of Booker is his work ethic. 
Booker made his season debut against Baylor, hauling in three catches for 39 yards including a 22-yard catch on third down to keep KU’s lone scoring drive alive. 
“He approaches the game like a pro does,” Beaty said. “I was looking at him yesterday, and he’s obviously — he’s a big dude already, but he’s got some growing left to do.” 
Beaty compared Booker to Iowa State’s Allen Lazard, who Beaty recruited during his time at Texas A&M. Lazard caught six balls for 75 yards and a score against KU earlier this season. 
Booker has a certain aggressiveness at the receiver position that not all freshmen possess. When a pass goes up, Booker attacks it while it’s in the air and uses his hand strength to beat the defender. 
“You can teach it,” Beaty said. “We say all the time the only way to get better at catching the ball in any different area is to do it a lot. It’s muscle memory.” 
Offensive coordinator Rob Likens said that before Booker’s left shoulder injury injury suffered in early August, he and Beaty saw him as an immediate contributor. Booker is one of five true freshmen receivers KU has on its roster who have combined for 16 catches. 
“You look out there one time and I think we had five true freshmen on offense at once,” Likens said. “(Booker) is always where he’s supposed to be. Sometimes freshmen are a little squirrelly.” 
Taylor said it came as no surprise that Booker made an impact when he stepped on the field. He described Booker’s attitude as quiet and said he is a player who is “keeping his nose to the grindstone.” 
That type of attitude fits perfectly into Beaty’s “earn it” philosophy. Beaty said this can be an exciting time for a freshman like Booker. 
Beaty described Booker as having big eyes when he came to the sideline after his first catch Saturday. Beaty reminded him that it was the first catch of his career, and Booker said, “I’m ready to go now.” 
Beaty thinks Booker will have a bright future because of his size and determination. His body might change throughout his time at KU, but Beaty believes one thing that won’t change is his work ethic. 
“When I think of him, I think of a guy that is a tireless worker,” Beaty said. “He takes care of his body in the training room and the weight room. Everybody that has really been around him has talked about him being a pro.”
